case_vignette:
A 10-year-old boy is brought in by his mother with increasing abdominal pain for the past week. The patient’s mother says he has been almost constantly nauseous over that time. She denies any change in his bowel habits, fever, chills, sick contacts or recent travel. The patient has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. The patient is at the 90th percentile for height and weight and has been meeting all developmental milestones. The temperature is 36.8℃ (98.2℉). On physical examination, the patient’s abdomen is asymmetrically distended. Bowel sounds are normoactive. No lymphadenopathy is noted. A cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Palpation of the right flank and right iliac fossa reveals a 10 × 10 cm firm mass which is immobile and tender. The laboratory findings are significant for the following: 
Hemoglobin 10 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 88 μm3
Leukocyte count 8,000/mm3
Platelet count 150,000/mm3
    Serum creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) 1,000 U/L
An ultrasound-guided needle biopsy of the flank mass was performed, and the histopathologic findings are shown in the exhibit (see image).
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having increasing abdominal pain for the past week and feeling almost constantly nauseous.
Great, thank you for sharing that information. Can you tell me more about the nature of the abdominal pain? Is it sharp or dull, and does it radiate to any other areas of your body?
It's just a really bad pain in my belly, but I haven't noticed it going anywhere else.

Thank you for clarifying. Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you some questions about your medical history. Have you had any previous surgeries or illnesses that could be related to your current symptoms?
No, I haven't had any surgeries or big illnesses before.
Okay, that's helpful to know. Have you noticed any other symptoms such as fever, fatigue, or changes in your bowel movements?
No fever, chills, or changes in how I go to the bathroom.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to perform a physical examination to help narrow down the possible causes of your abdominal pain. Can you please lie on your back on the examination table so I can perform a thorough examination?

Great! Please lie down on the examination table and let me know when you are comfortable. I will then begin the examination.

Can you please tell me, have you noticed any changes in your appetite or weight recently?

Alright, I'm on my side now with my hand on my belly.
Great, thank you. Listening to your heart and lungs... (pauses) Everything sounds normal so far. Can you please tell me, have you noticed any changes in your menstrual cycle or any vaginal bleeding?
I'm a boy, so I don't have those.

Okay, no problem! Based on your symptoms, I'm going to take a wild guess and say that you might have appendicitis. I know it's a bit of a stretch, but the abdominal pain and nausea you're experiencing are classic symptoms of appendicitis. Of course, there are other possible causes of abdominal pain, so we'll need to do some more testing to confirm the diagnosis.

Do you have any questions about appendicitis or the testing we'll need to do?
No, I don't have any questions right now. Thank you.

Great, thank you for your cooperation. I will now proceed with the testing to confirm the diagnosis. I will need to perform a physical examination and some diagnostic tests, such as a CT scan or an ultrasound, to rule out other possible causes of your abdominal pain.

Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns during the testing process. And remember, if you experience any severe abdominal pain, difficulty breathing, or loss of consciousness, please seek medical attention immediately.

Thank you for your cooperation.

The CT scan will take about 30 minutes to an hour to complete, and you will need to drink a special contrast dye to help the imaging technology detect any abnormalities. The dye is usually given through a small tube inserted into a vein in your arm, and it will make you feel a little warm and tingly for a few minutes.
